intro: Astragalus amplexus, commonly known as the clasping milkvetch, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, pea-like flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to arid conditions. It has a deep root system that helps it survive in nutrient-poor soils. Astragalus amplexus is also valued for its ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing nectar for pollinators.
